abstract.p: Jennifer Moses Op-Ed article on capri pants, current fashion trend, even among urban sophisticates and professional women; drawing (M)

block.p: I suffer from shopping anxiety, no doubt because nothing looks good on me now that I'm past the age I never thought it was possible to be in the first place. But it doesn't really matter these days anyway, since most women's clothing seems to be designed for skinny 14-year-olds.

Nevertheless, every once in a while, when my children say something like, ''Hey, Mom, the 60's are over,'' as they did a couple of weeks ago, I jump in the minivan and drive to the mall looking for something to update my wardrobe.

I suffer from shopping anxiety, no doubt because nothing looks good on me now that I'm past the age I never thought it was possible to be in the first place. But it doesn't really matter these days anyway, since most women's clothing seems to be designed for skinny 14-year-olds.

Nevertheless, every once in a while, when my children say something like, ''Hey, Mom, the 60's are over,'' as they did a couple of weeks ago, I jump in the minivan and drive to the mall looking for something to update my wardrobe.

This time I didn't do well. At the Gap, the store I've relied on for years to supply me with blue jeans in progressively bigger sizes and white T-shirts in a seemingly inexhaustible variety, I could find nothing but capris -- those tight, above-the-ankle pants that have spread from coast to coast like some terrifying virus.
Capri pants and the little cropped shirts designed to go with them hung on every hanger, in brilliant yellow, magenta, purple passion, lollipop lime and poppy red. I tried on a few pair.

''You look cute,'' the saleswoman said as I emerged in one after another pair of the tiny pants and the matching little tops that made me look like a linebacker in fancy dress or, more accurately, a fairly thin, 5-foot-4, middle-aged mom pushing the envelope in a big, big way. Who was she kidding?

The things weren't even comfortable to begin with, let alone cheap. And what was with my calves, anyway? Why did they look so -- large? My legs are thin, so thin that in high school my best friend called me ''Stick Legs,'' and I used our own 60's fashion must-have, Frye boots, to hide them.

But now I feel . . . what is the word? Old? Dowdy? But I'm none of the above. Thus I pushed on: Banana Republic, Urban Outfitters, the Limited, Old Navy, Sears. I also needed a bathing suit, but how can a woman locate a bathing suit when the entire mall seems devoted to capri pants?

What is it with the fashion industry, anyway? Because, suddenly, I saw capri pants not just in the mall, but everywhere: at the grocery store, on the mothers of my children's friends, on my neighbors, and on the women who gathered recently at a fancy art opening for another friend, who was also wearing capri pants. Perhaps, I thought, this was just one of those fashion trends that catches on only among gullible people in Baton Rouge.

But, no, it seems that actual urban sophisticates, professional women with cell phones and expense accounts, are wearing them, too. My sister, who lives on the Upper West Side in Manhattan and is a lawyer, reports that Zabar's is full of capri-clad women, and that at her law firm, they have become a staple of casual Friday wardrobes. Lawyers in capris? In Manhattan? Don't they know we're wearing them on the Bayou, too?
Even my own 6-year-old daughter has a pair. Actually, she is the one person I know who looks good in them. After all, they were made for her.
Jennifer Moses is the author of ''Food and Whine: Confessions of a New Millennium Mom.''
